Senate File 215 - Introduced


                                 SENATE FILE 

                                 SENATE FILE 
                                 SENATE FILE                                  SENATE FILE                                  BY  BOLKCOM, TAYLOR, and
                                     McCOY

 A BILL FOR

  1 An Act creating the Iowa end=of=life options Act and providing
  2    penalties.
  3 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:
    TLSB 1402XS (3) 87
    pf/nh

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.                                       McCOY

  2    penalties.

  1  1    Section 1.    3 BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF IOWA:

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.      TLSB 1402XS (3) 87
    pf/nh

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.      pf/nh

PAG LIN



  1  1    Section 1.  

  1  1    Section 1.  
  1  1    Section 1.    1  1    Section 1.    1  2    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Iowa
  1  3 End=of=Life Options Act".
  1  4    Sec. 2.    1  3 End=of=Life Options Act".
  1  4    Sec. 2.    1  4    Sec. 2.    1  5    As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise
  1  6 requires:
  1  7    1.  "Adult" means an individual who is eighteen years of age
  1  8 or older.
  1  9    2.  "Attending physician" means the physician who has primary
  1 10 responsibility for the  care of the patient and treatment of the
  1 11 patient's terminal disease.
  1 12    3.  "Competent" means that in the opinion of a court or in
  1 13 the opinion of the patient's  attending physician or consulting
  1 14 physician, psychiatrist, or psychologist, a patient has  the
  1 15 ability to make and communicate health care decisions to
  1 16 health care providers,  including communication through persons
  1 17 familiar with the patient's manner of  communicating if those
  1 18 persons are available.
  1 19    4.  "Consulting physician" means a physician who is qualified
  1 20 by specialty or experience  to make a professional diagnosis and
  1 21 prognosis regarding the patient's disease.
  1 22    5.  "Counseling" means one or more consultations as necessary
  1 23 between a licensed psychiatrist or psychologist and a patient
  1 24 for the purpose of determining that  the patient is competent
  1 25 and not suffering from a psychiatric or psychological disorder
  1 26 or  depression causing impaired judgment.
  1 27    6.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  1 28    7.  "Health care facility" means a health care facility as
  1 29 defined in section 135C.1.
  1 30    8.  "Health care provider" means a person licensed,
  1 31 certified, or otherwise authorized or  permitted by the law of
  1 32 this state to administer health care or dispense medication in
  1 33 the ordinary course of business or practice of a profession,
  1 34 and includes a health care  facility.
  1 35    9.  "Informed decision" means a decision by a qualified
  2  1 patient to request and obtain a  prescription to end the
  2  2 patient's life that is based on an  appreciation of the relevant
  2  3 facts and after being fully informed by the attending  physician
  2  4 of all of the following:
  2  5    a.  The patient's medical diagnosis.
  2  6    b.  The patient's  prognosis.
  2  7    c.  The potential risks associated with taking the medication
  2  8 to be prescribed.
  2  9    d.  The probable result of taking the medication to be
  2 10 prescribed.
  2 11    e.  The feasible alternatives, including but not limited to
  2 12 comfort care, hospice care,  and pain control.
  2 13    10.  "Long=term care facility" means  a long=term care unit
  2 14 of a hospital,  a health care facility, an elder group home as
  2 15 defined in section 231B.1, or an assisted living program as
  2 16 defined in section 231C.2.
  2 17    11.  "Medically confirmed" means the medical opinion of
  2 18 the attending physician has  been confirmed by a consulting
  2 19 physician who has examined the patient and the  patient's
  2 20 relevant medical records.
  2 21    12.  "Patient" means a person who is under the care of a
  2 22 physician.
  2 23    13.  "Physician" means a person licensed to practice medicine
  2 24 and surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery under chapter
  2 25 148.
  2 26    14.  "Qualified patient" means a competent adult who is a
  2 27 resident of Iowa and has  satisfied the requirements of this
  2 28 chapter  to obtain a prescription  for medication to end the
  2 29 individual's life.
  2 30    15.  "Self=administer" means a qualified patient's act of
  2 31 ingesting medication to end the patient's life.
  2 32    16.  "Terminal disease" means an incurable and irreversible
  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.
  2 35    Sec. 3.    1  6 requires:
  1  7    1.  "Adult" means an individual who is eighteen years of age
  1  8 or older.
  1  9    2.  "Attending physician" means the physician who has primary
  1 10 responsibility for the  care of the patient and treatment of the
  1 11 patient's terminal disease.
  1 12    3.  "Competent" means that in the opinion of a court or in
  1 13 the opinion of the patient's  attending physician or consulting
  1 14 physician, psychiatrist, or psychologist, a patient has  the
  1 15 ability to make and communicate health care decisions to
  1 16 health care providers,  including communication through persons
  1 17 familiar with the patient's manner of  communicating if those
  1 18 persons are available.
  1 19    4.  "Consulting physician" means a physician who is qualified
  1 20 by specialty or experience  to make a professional diagnosis and
  1 21 prognosis regarding the patient's disease.
  1 22    5.  "Counseling" means one or more consultations as necessary
  1 23 between a licensed psychiatrist or psychologist and a patient
  1 24 for the purpose of determining that  the patient is competent
  1 25 and not suffering from a psychiatric or psychological disorder
  1 26 or  depression causing impaired judgment.
  1 27    6.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  1 28    7.  "Health care facility" means a health care facility as
  1 29 defined in section 135C.1.
  1 30    8.  "Health care provider" means a person licensed,
  1 31 certified, or otherwise authorized or  permitted by the law of
  1 32 this state to administer health care or dispense medication in
  1 33 the ordinary course of business or practice of a profession,
  1 34 and includes a health care  facility.
  1 35    9.  "Informed decision" means a decision by a qualified
  2  1 patient to request and obtain a  prescription to end the
  2  2 patient's life that is based on an  appreciation of the relevant
  2  3 facts and after being fully informed by the attending  physician
  2  4 of all of the following:
  2  5    a.  The patient's medical diagnosis.
  2  6    b.  The patient's  prognosis.
  2  7    c.  The potential risks associated with taking the medication
  2  8 to be prescribed.
  2  9    d.  The probable result of taking the medication to be
  2 10 prescribed.
  2 11    e.  The feasible alternatives, including but not limited to
  2 12 comfort care, hospice care,  and pain control.
  2 13    10.  "Long=term care facility" means  a long=term care unit
  2 14 of a hospital,  a health care facility, an elder group home as
  2 15 defined in section 231B.1, or an assisted living program as
  2 16 defined in section 231C.2.
  2 17    11.  "Medically confirmed" means the medical opinion of
  2 18 the attending physician has  been confirmed by a consulting
  2 19 physician who has examined the patient and the  patient's
  2 20 relevant medical records.
  2 21    12.  "Patient" means a person who is under the care of a
  2 22 physician.
  2 23    13.  "Physician" means a person licensed to practice medicine
  2 24 and surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery under chapter
  2 25 148.
  2 26    14.  "Qualified patient" means a competent adult who is a
  2 27 resident of Iowa and has  satisfied the requirements of this
  2 28 chapter  to obtain a prescription  for medication to end the
  2 29 individual's life.
  2 30    15.  "Self=administer" means a qualified patient's act of
  2 31 ingesting medication to end the patient's life.
  2 32    16.  "Terminal disease" means an incurable and irreversible
  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.
  2 35    Sec. 3.    1  7    1.  "Adult" means an individual who is eighteen years of age

  1 23 between a licensed psychiatrist or psychologist and a patient
  1 24 for the purpose of determining that  the patient is competent
  1 25 and not suffering from a psychiatric or psychological disorder
  1 26 or  depression causing impaired judgment.
  1 27    6.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  1 28    7.  "Health care facility" means a health care facility as
  1 29 defined in section 135C.1.
  1 30    8.  "Health care provider" means a person licensed,
  1 31 certified, or otherwise authorized or  permitted by the law of
  1 32 this state to administer health care or dispense medication in
  1 33 the ordinary course of business or practice of a profession,
  1 34 and includes a health care  facility.
  1 35    9.  "Informed decision" means a decision by a qualified
  2  1 patient to request and obtain a  prescription to end the
  2  2 patient's life that is based on an  appreciation of the relevant
  2  3 facts and after being fully informed by the attending  physician
  2  4 of all of the following:
  2  5    a.  The patient's medical diagnosis.
  2  6    b.  The patient's  prognosis.
  2  7    c.  The potential risks associated with taking the medication
  2  8 to be prescribed.
  2  9    d.  The probable result of taking the medication to be
  2 10 prescribed.
  2 11    e.  The feasible alternatives, including but not limited to
  2 12 comfort care, hospice care,  and pain control.
  2 13    10.  "Long=term care facility" means  a long=term care unit
  2 14 of a hospital,  a health care facility, an elder group home as
  2 15 defined in section 231B.1, or an assisted living program as
  2 16 defined in section 231C.2.
  2 17    11.  "Medically confirmed" means the medical opinion of
  2 18 the attending physician has  been confirmed by a consulting
  2 19 physician who has examined the patient and the  patient's
  2 20 relevant medical records.
  2 21    12.  "Patient" means a person who is under the care of a
  2 22 physician.
  2 23    13.  "Physician" means a person licensed to practice medicine
  2 24 and surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery under chapter
  2 25 148.
  2 26    14.  "Qualified patient" means a competent adult who is a
  2 27 resident of Iowa and has  satisfied the requirements of this
  2 28 chapter  to obtain a prescription  for medication to end the
  2 29 individual's life.
  2 30    15.  "Self=administer" means a qualified patient's act of
  2 31 ingesting medication to end the patient's life.
  2 32    16.  "Terminal disease" means an incurable and irreversible
  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.
  2 35    Sec. 3.    1 13 the opinion of the patient's  attending physician or consulting
  1 14 physician, psychiatrist, or psychologist, a patient has  the
  1 15 ability to make and communicate health care decisions to
  1 16 health care providers,  including communication through persons
  1 17 familiar with the patient's manner of  communicating if those
  1 18 persons are available.
  1 19    4.  "Consulting physician" means a physician who is qualified
  1 20 by specialty or experience  to make a professional diagnosis and
  1 21 prognosis regarding the patient's disease.
  1 22    5.  "Counseling" means one or more consultations as necessary
  1 23 between a licensed psychiatrist or psychologist and a patient
  1 24 for the purpose of determining that  the patient is competent
  1 25 and not suffering from a psychiatric or psychological disorder
  1 26 or  depression causing impaired judgment.

  2 11    e.  The feasible alternatives, including but not limited to
  2 12 comfort care, hospice care,  and pain control.
  2 13    10.  "Long=term care facility" means  a long=term care unit
  2 14 of a hospital,  a health care facility, an elder group home as
  2 15 defined in section 231B.1, or an assisted living program as
  2 16 defined in section 231C.2.
  2 17    11.  "Medically confirmed" means the medical opinion of
  2 18 the attending physician has  been confirmed by a consulting
  2 19 physician who has examined the patient and the  patient's
  2 20 relevant medical records.
  2 21    12.  "Patient" means a person who is under the care of a
  2 22 physician.
  2 23    13.  "Physician" means a person licensed to practice medicine
  2 24 and surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery under chapter
  2 25 148.
  2 26    14.  "Qualified patient" means a competent adult who is a
  2 27 resident of Iowa and has  satisfied the requirements of this
  2 28 chapter  to obtain a prescription  for medication to end the
  2 29 individual's life.
  2 30    15.  "Self=administer" means a qualified patient's act of
  2 31 ingesting medication to end the patient's life.
  2 32    16.  "Terminal disease" means an incurable and irreversible
  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.
  2 35    Sec. 3.    1 22    5.  "Counseling" means one or more consultations as necessary
  1 23 between a licensed psychiatrist or psychologist and a patient
  1 24 for the purpose of determining that  the patient is competent
  1 25 and not suffering from a psychiatric or psychological disorder
  1 26 or  depression causing impaired judgment.
  1 27    6.  "Department" means the department of public health.
  1 28    7.  "Health care facility" means a health care facility as
  1 29 defined in section 135C.1.
  1 30    8.  "Health care provider" means a person licensed,
  1 31 certified, or otherwise authorized or  permitted by the law of
  1 32 this state to administer health care or dispense medication in
  1 33 the ordinary course of business or practice of a profession,
  1 34 and includes a health care  facility.
  1 35    9.  "Informed decision" means a decision by a qualified
  2  1 patient to request and obtain a  prescription to end the
  2  2 patient's life that is based on an  appreciation of the relevant
  2  3 facts and after being fully informed by the attending  physician
  2  4 of all of the following:
  2  5    a.  The patient's medical diagnosis.
  2  6    b.  The patient's  prognosis.
  2  7    c.  The potential risks associated with taking the medication
  2  8 to be prescribed.
  2  9    d.  The probable result of taking the medication to be
  2 10 prescribed.
  2 11    e.  The feasible alternatives, including but not limited to
  2 12 comfort care, hospice care,  and pain control.

  2 32    16.  "Terminal disease" means an incurable and irreversible
  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.
  2 35    Sec. 3.    1 33 the ordinary course of business or practice of a profession,
  1 34 and includes a health care  facility.
  1 35    9.  "Informed decision" means a decision by a qualified
  2  1 patient to request and obtain a  prescription to end the
  2  2 patient's life that is based on an  appreciation of the relevant
  2  3 facts and after being fully informed by the attending  physician
  2  4 of all of the following:
  2  5    a.  The patient's medical diagnosis.
  2  6    b.  The patient's  prognosis.
  2  7    c.  The potential risks associated with taking the medication
  2  8 to be prescribed.
  2  9    d.  The probable result of taking the medication to be
  2 10 prescribed.
  2 11    e.  The feasible alternatives, including but not limited to
  2 12 comfort care, hospice care,  and pain control.
  2 13    10.  "Long=term care facility" means  a long=term care unit
  2 14 of a hospital,  a health care facility, an elder group home as
  2 15 defined in section 231B.1, or an assisted living program as
  2 16 defined in section 231C.2.
  2 17    11.  "Medically confirmed" means the medical opinion of
  2 18 the attending physician has  been confirmed by a consulting
  2 19 physician who has examined the patient and the  patient's
  2 20 relevant medical records.
  2 21    12.  "Patient" means a person who is under the care of a
  2 22 physician.
  2 23    13.  "Physician" means a person licensed to practice medicine
  2 24 and surgery or osteopathic medicine and surgery under chapter
  2 25 148.
  2 26    14.  "Qualified patient" means a competent adult who is a
  2 27 resident of Iowa and has  satisfied the requirements of this
  2 28 chapter  to obtain a prescription  for medication to end the
  2 29 individual's life.

  2 31 ingesting medication to end the patient's life.

  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.

  2 33 disease that has been  medically confirmed and that will, within
  2 34 reasonable medical judgment, produce death within  six months.
  2 35    Sec. 3.    2 15 defined in section 231B.1, or an assisted living program as
  2 16 defined in section 231C.2.

  2 18 the attending physician has  been confirmed by a consulting
  2 19 physician who has examined the patient and the  patient's
  2 20 relevant medical records.

  2 22 physician.

  2 35    Sec. 3.    2 35    Sec. 3.    3  1    1.  An adult patient who is competent, is a resident of
  3  2 this state, has been determined by the patient's attending
  3  3 physician and consulting physician to be suffering from a
  3  4 terminal disease, and has  voluntarily expressed a wish to die,
  3  5 may make a written request for medication that the patient may
  3  6 self=administer to end the patient's life in accordance with
  3  7 this chapter.
  3  8    2.  A person shall not qualify to make a written request
  3  9 under this section solely  because of age or disability.

  3 10    Sec. 4.    3 10    Sec. 4.    3 11 right to rescind.
  3 12    1.  To receive a prescription for medication that a qualified
  3 13 patient may self=administer to end the qualified  patient's life
  3 14 pursuant to this chapter, the qualified patient shall make an
  3 15 initial oral request, followed by a subsequent oral request
  3 16 at least fifteen days after the initial oral request, and a
  3 17 written request to the qualified patient's attending physician.
  3 18    2.  At least fifteen days shall elapse between a qualified
  3 19 patient's initial oral request and the writing of a
  3 20 prescription under this chapter.
  3 21    3.  At least forty=eight hours shall elapse between the
  3 22 submission of a qualified patient's written request and the
  3 23 writing of a prescription under this chapter.
  3 24    4.  a.  At the time the qualified patient makes the second
  3 25 oral request, the attending physician shall offer the qualified
  3 26 patient an opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 27    b.  A patient may rescind a request for a prescription for
  3 28 medication under this chapter at any time and in any manner
  3 29 without regard to the patient's  mental state. A prescription
  3 30 for medication under this chapter shall not be written prior
  3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 12    1.  To receive a prescription for medication that a qualified
  3 13 patient may self=administer to end the qualified  patient's life
  3 14 pursuant to this chapter, the qualified patient shall make an
  3 15 initial oral request, followed by a subsequent oral request
  3 16 at least fifteen days after the initial oral request, and a
  3 17 written request to the qualified patient's attending physician.

  3 29 without regard to the patient's  mental state. A prescription

  3 27    b.  A patient may rescind a request for a prescription for
  3 28 medication under this chapter at any time and in any manner
  3 29 without regard to the patient's  mental state. A prescription
  3 30 for medication under this chapter shall not be written prior
  3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 27    b.  A patient may rescind a request for a prescription for
  3 28 medication under this chapter at any time and in any manner
  3 29 without regard to the patient's  mental state. A prescription
  3 30 for medication under this chapter shall not be written prior
  3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 28 medication under this chapter at any time and in any manner
  3 29 without regard to the patient's  mental state. A prescription
  3 30 for medication under this chapter shall not be written prior
  3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 29 without regard to the patient's  mental state. A prescription
  3 30 for medication under this chapter shall not be written prior
  3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 30 for medication under this chapter shall not be written prior
  3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 31 to the  attending physician offering the qualified patient an
  3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 32 opportunity to rescind the request.
  3 33    Sec. 5.    3 33    Sec. 5.    3 34 witnesses.
  3 35    1.  A qualified patient who is unable to orally communicate
  4  1 may make a valid oral request under this chapter by reducing
  4  2 the oral request to writing for submission to the qualified
  4  3 patient's attending physician. Such writing is not subject
  4  4 to the requirements otherwise applicable to a written request
  4  5 under this chapter.
  4  6    2.  a.  A valid written request for medication under  this
  4  7 chapter shall be in substantially the form described in section
  4  8 142E.17, shall be  signed and dated by the patient, and shall
  4  9 be witnessed by at least two individuals who, in the presence
  4 10 of the patient, attest that to the best of their knowledge and
  4 11 belief the patient is competent, acting voluntarily, and is not
  4 12 being coerced to sign the request.
  4 13    b.  One of the witnesses shall be a person who is not any of
  4 14 the following:
  4 15    (1)  A relative of the patient by blood, marriage, or
  4 16 adoption.
  4 17    (2)  A person who at the time the request is signed would be
  4 18 entitled to any portion of  the estate of the patient upon death
  4 19 under any will or by operation of law.
  4 20    (3)  An owner, operator, or employee of a long=term care
  4 21 facility where the patient  is receiving medical treatment or
  4 22 is a resident.
  4 23    c.  The patient's attending physician at the time the request
  4 24 is signed shall not be a witness.
  4 25    d.  If the patient is a patient in a long=term care facility
  4 26 at the time the written request  is made, one of the witnesses
  4 27 shall be an individual designated by the facility and  having
  4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.
  4 29    Sec. 6.    3 35    1.  A qualified patient who is unable to orally communicate
  4  1 may make a valid oral request under this chapter by reducing
  4  2 the oral request to writing for submission to the qualified
  4  3 patient's attending physician. Such writing is not subject
  4  4 to the requirements otherwise applicable to a written request
  4  5 under this chapter.

  4 22 is a resident.

  4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.

  4 29    Sec. 6.    4 24 is signed shall not be a witness.
  4 25    d.  If the patient is a patient in a long=term care facility
  4 26 at the time the written request  is made, one of the witnesses
  4 27 shall be an individual designated by the facility and  having
  4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.
  4 29    Sec. 6.    4 25    d.  If the patient is a patient in a long=term care facility
  4 26 at the time the written request  is made, one of the witnesses
  4 27 shall be an individual designated by the facility and  having
  4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.
  4 29    Sec. 6.    4 26 at the time the written request  is made, one of the witnesses
  4 27 shall be an individual designated by the facility and  having
  4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.
  4 29    Sec. 6.    4 27 shall be an individual designated by the facility and  having
  4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.
  4 29    Sec. 6.    4 28 the qualifications specified by the department by rule.
  4 29    Sec. 6.    4 29    Sec. 6.    4 30 responsibilities.
  4 31    1.  The attending physician shall do all of the following:
  4 32    a.  Make the initial determination of whether a patient has
  4 33 a terminal disease, is  competent, and has made the request for
  4 34 medication under this chapter voluntarily.
  4 35    b.  Request that the patient demonstrate residency in the
  5  1 state. Factors demonstrating residency in this state include
  5  2 but are not limited to:
  5  3    (1)  Possession of an Iowa driver's license or a
  5  4 nonoperator's identification card.
  5  5    (2)  Registration to vote in Iowa.
  5  6    (3)  Evidence that the person owns or leases property in
  5  7 Iowa.
  5  8    (4)  Filing of an Iowa tax return for the most recent tax
  5  9 year.
  5 10    c.  Verify immediately prior to writing the prescription for
  5 11 medication, that the patient is making an informed decision.
  5 12    d.  Refer the patient to a consulting physician for medical
  5 13 confirmation of the diagnosis,  and for a determination that the
  5 14 patient is competent and acting voluntarily.
  5 15    e.  Refer the patient for counseling if appropriate under
  5 16 section 142E.8.
  5 17    f.  Recommend that the patient notify next of kin. However,
  5 18 a qualified patient's request for medication shall not
  5 19 be denied based on the qualified patient's declination or
  5 20 inability to notify next of kin.
  5 21    g.  Counsel the patient about the importance of having
  5 22 another person present when  the patient takes the medication
  5 23 prescribed and of not taking the medication in a public place.
  5 24    h.  Inform the patient that the patient has an opportunity
  5 25 to rescind the request at any time and in any manner, and offer
  5 26 the patient an opportunity to rescind the request at the end of
  5 27 the fifteen=day waiting period under section 142E.4.
  5 28    i.  Fulfill the medical record documentation requirements
  5 29 under section 142E.9.
  5 30    j.  Ensure that all appropriate steps are carried out in
  5 31 accordance with this chapter prior to writing a prescription
  5 32 for medication to enable a qualified patient to end the
  5 33 patient's life.
  5 34    k.  Do either of the following:
  5 35    (1)  Dispense medications directly, including ancillary
  6  1 medications intended to  facilitate the desired effect to
  6  2 minimize the patient's discomfort, if the attending physician
  6  3 is authorized under law and rule to dispense such medication
  6  4 and has a current valid drug enforcement administration number,
  6  5 if required under chapter 124.
  6  6    (2)  With the patient's written consent:
  6  7    (a)  Contact a pharmacist and inform the pharmacist of the
  6  8 prescription.
  6  9    (b)  Deliver the written prescription personally, by
  6 10 mail, or by facsimile  to the pharmacist who will dispense the
  6 11 medications to either the patient, the attending physician, or
  6 12 an expressly  identified agent of the patient.
  6 13    2.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  6 14 contrary, the attending physician may sign the patient's death
  6 15 certificate.
  6 16    Sec. 7.    4 31    1.  The attending physician shall do all of the following:
  4 32    a.  Make the initial determination of whether a patient has
  4 33 a terminal disease, is  competent, and has made the request for
  4 34 medication under this chapter voluntarily.
  4 35    b.  Request that the patient demonstrate residency in the
  5  1 state. Factors demonstrating residency in this state include
  5  2 but are not limited to:

  5  4 nonoperator's identification card.

  5  7 Iowa.
  5  8    (4)  Filing of an Iowa tax return for the most recent tax
  5  9 year.

  5 26 the patient an opportunity to rescind the request at the end of

  6 15 certificate.

  5 26 the patient an opportunity to rescind the request at the end of
  5 27 the fifteen=day waiting period under section 142E.4.
  5 28    i.  Fulfill the medical record documentation requirements
  5 29 under section 142E.9.
  5 30    j.  Ensure that all appropriate steps are carried out in
  5 31 accordance with this chapter prior to writing a prescription
  5 32 for medication to enable a qualified patient to end the
  5 33 patient's life.
  5 34    k.  Do either of the following:
  5 35    (1)  Dispense medications directly, including ancillary
  6  1 medications intended to  facilitate the desired effect to
  6  2 minimize the patient's discomfort, if the attending physician
  6  3 is authorized under law and rule to dispense such medication
  6  4 and has a current valid drug enforcement administration number,
  6  5 if required under chapter 124.
  6  6    (2)  With the patient's written consent:
  6  7    (a)  Contact a pharmacist and inform the pharmacist of the
  6  8 prescription.
  6  9    (b)  Deliver the written prescription personally, by
  6 10 mail, or by facsimile  to the pharmacist who will dispense the
  6 11 medications to either the patient, the attending physician, or
  6 12 an expressly  identified agent of the patient.
  6 13    2.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  6 14 contrary, the attending physician may sign the patient's death
  6 15 certificate.
  6 16    Sec. 7.    5  5    (2)  Registration to vote in Iowa.
  5  6    (3)  Evidence that the person owns or leases property in
  5  7 Iowa.
  5  8    (4)  Filing of an Iowa tax return for the most recent tax
  5  9 year.
  5 10    c.  Verify immediately prior to writing the prescription for
  5 11 medication, that the patient is making an informed decision.
  5 12    d.  Refer the patient to a consulting physician for medical
  5 13 confirmation of the diagnosis,  and for a determination that the
  5 14 patient is competent and acting voluntarily.
  5 15    e.  Refer the patient for counseling if appropriate under
  5 16 section 142E.8.
  5 17    f.  Recommend that the patient notify next of kin. However,
  5 18 a qualified patient's request for medication shall not
  5 19 be denied based on the qualified patient's declination or
  5 20 inability to notify next of kin.
  5 21    g.  Counsel the patient about the importance of having
  5 22 another person present when  the patient takes the medication
  5 23 prescribed and of not taking the medication in a public place.
  5 24    h.  Inform the patient that the patient has an opportunity
  5 25 to rescind the request at any time and in any manner, and offer
  5 26 the patient an opportunity to rescind the request at the end of
  5 27 the fifteen=day waiting period under section 142E.4.
  5 28    i.  Fulfill the medical record documentation requirements
  5 29 under section 142E.9.
  5 30    j.  Ensure that all appropriate steps are carried out in
  5 31 accordance with this chapter prior to writing a prescription
  5 32 for medication to enable a qualified patient to end the
  5 33 patient's life.

  6 11 medications to either the patient, the attending physician, or
  6 12 an expressly  identified agent of the patient.
  6 13    2.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  6 14 contrary, the attending physician may sign the patient's death
  6 15 certificate.
  6 16    Sec. 7.    5 17    f.  Recommend that the patient notify next of kin. However,
  5 18 a qualified patient's request for medication shall not
  5 19 be denied based on the qualified patient's declination or
  5 20 inability to notify next of kin.
  5 21    g.  Counsel the patient about the importance of having
  5 22 another person present when  the patient takes the medication
  5 23 prescribed and of not taking the medication in a public place.
  5 24    h.  Inform the patient that the patient has an opportunity
  5 25 to rescind the request at any time and in any manner, and offer
  5 26 the patient an opportunity to rescind the request at the end of
  5 27 the fifteen=day waiting period under section 142E.4.
  5 28    i.  Fulfill the medical record documentation requirements
  5 29 under section 142E.9.
  5 30    j.  Ensure that all appropriate steps are carried out in
  5 31 accordance with this chapter prior to writing a prescription
  5 32 for medication to enable a qualified patient to end the
  5 33 patient's life.
  5 34    k.  Do either of the following:
  5 35    (1)  Dispense medications directly, including ancillary
  6  1 medications intended to  facilitate the desired effect to
  6  2 minimize the patient's discomfort, if the attending physician
  6  3 is authorized under law and rule to dispense such medication
  6  4 and has a current valid drug enforcement administration number,
  6  5 if required under chapter 124.
  6  6    (2)  With the patient's written consent:
  6  7    (a)  Contact a pharmacist and inform the pharmacist of the
  6  8 prescription.
  6  9    (b)  Deliver the written prescription personally, by
  6 10 mail, or by facsimile  to the pharmacist who will dispense the
  6 11 medications to either the patient, the attending physician, or
  6 12 an expressly  identified agent of the patient.
  6 13    2.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  6 14 contrary, the attending physician may sign the patient's death
  6 15 certificate.
  6 16    Sec. 7.    5 18 a qualified patient's request for medication shall not
  5 19 be denied based on the qualified patient's declination or
  5 20 inability to notify next of kin.
  5 21    g.  Counsel the patient about the importance of having
  5 22 another person present when  the patient takes the medication
  5 23 prescribed and of not taking the medication in a public place.
  5 24    h.  Inform the patient that the patient has an opportunity
  5 25 to rescind the request at any time and in any manner, and offer
  5 26 the patient an opportunity to rescind the request at the end of
  5 27 the fifteen=day waiting period under section 142E.4.
  5 28    i.  Fulfill the medical record documentation requirements

  6 14 contrary, the attending physician may sign the patient's death
  6 15 certificate.
  6 16    Sec. 7.    6  3 is authorized under law and rule to dispense such medication
  6  4 and has a current valid drug enforcement administration number,
  6  5 if required under chapter 124.
  6  6    (2)  With the patient's written consent:
  6  7    (a)  Contact a pharmacist and inform the pharmacist of the
  6  8 prescription.
  6  9    (b)  Deliver the written prescription personally, by
  6 10 mail, or by facsimile  to the pharmacist who will dispense the
  6 11 medications to either the patient, the attending physician, or
  6 12 an expressly  identified agent of the patient.

  6 14 contrary, the attending physician may sign the patient's death
  6 15 certificate.

  6 16    Sec. 7.    6 16    Sec. 7.    6 17 confirmation.
  6 18    A consulting physician shall do all of the following in
  6 19 confirming that a patient is a qualified patient under this
  6 20 chapter:
  6 21    1.  Examine the patient and the patient's  relevant medical
  6 22 records and confirm, in writing, the attending physician's
  6 23 diagnosis that the patient is suffering from a terminal
  6 24 disease.
  6 25    2.  Verify that the patient is competent, acting
  6 26 voluntarily, and has made an informed decision.
  6 27    Sec. 8.    6 18    A consulting physician shall do all of the following in

  6 24 disease.

  6 27    Sec. 8.    6 26 voluntarily, and has made an informed decision.
  6 27    Sec. 8.    6 27    Sec. 8.    6 28    1.  If,  in the opinion of the attending physician or the
  6 29 consulting physician, a patient may be suffering from a
  6 30 psychiatric or psychological disorder or depression causing
  6 31 impaired judgment, either physician shall refer the patient for
  6 32 counseling.
  6 33    2.  An attending physician shall not prescribe medication to
  6 34 end a patient's life pursuant to this chapter until the person
  6 35 performing the counseling determines and verifies that the
  7  1 patient is not suffering from a psychiatric or psychological
  7  2 disorder or depression causing impaired judgment.

  7  3    Sec. 9.    7  3    Sec. 9.    7  4 requirements.
  7  5    All of the following shall be documented or filed in a
  7  6 patient's medical record in regard to a request for medication
  7  7 under this chapter:
  7  8    1.  All oral requests by a patient for medication to end the
  7  9 patient's life pursuant to this chapter.
  7 10    2.  All written requests by a patient for medication to end
  7 11 the patient's  life pursuant to this chapter.
  7 12    3.  The attending physician's diagnosis and prognosis
  7 13 and determinations that the patient is competent, is acting
  7 14 voluntarily, and has made an informed decision.
  7 15    4.  The consulting physician's diagnosis and prognosis
  7 16 and verification that the patient is competent, is acting
  7 17 voluntarily, and has made an informed decision.
  7 18    5.  A report of the outcome and determinations made during
  7 19 counseling, if performed.
  7 20    6.  The attending physician's offer to the patient to rescind
  7 21 the patient's request at the time of the patient's second oral
  7 22 request pursuant to section 142E.4.
  7 23    7.  A note by the attending physician indicating that all
  7 24 requirements under this chapter have been met and indicating
  7 25 the steps taken to carry out the request, including a notation
  7 26 of the medication prescribed.
  7 27    Sec. 10.    7  5    All of the following shall be documented or filed in a
  7  6 patient's medical record in regard to a request for medication
  7  7 under this chapter:
  7  8    1.  All oral requests by a patient for medication to end the
  7  9 patient's life pursuant to this chapter.
  7 10    2.  All written requests by a patient for medication to end
  7 11 the patient's  life pursuant to this chapter.
  7 12    3.  The attending physician's diagnosis and prognosis
  7 13 and determinations that the patient is competent, is acting
  7 14 voluntarily, and has made an informed decision.

  7 19 counseling, if performed.

  7 23    7.  A note by the attending physician indicating that all
  7 24 requirements under this chapter have been met and indicating
  7 25 the steps taken to carry out the request, including a notation
  7 26 of the medication prescribed.

  7 27    Sec. 10.    7 26 of the medication prescribed.
  7 27    Sec. 10.    7 27    Sec. 10.    7 28    1.  a.  The department shall require any health care
  7 29 provider, upon dispensing medication  pursuant to this chapter,
  7 30 to file a copy of the dispensing record with the department.
  7 31    b.  The department shall annually review a sample of records
  7 32 maintained under this chapter.
  7 33    2.  The department shall adopt rules to facilitate the
  7 34 collection of information regarding compliance with this
  7 35 chapter.  Except as otherwise required by law, the information
  8  1 collected shall not be a public record and shall not be made
  8  2 available for  inspection by the public.
  8  3    3.  The department shall generate and make available to the
  8  4 public an annual statistical report of information collected
  8  5 under subsection 2.
  8  6    Sec. 11.    7 29 provider, upon dispensing medication  pursuant to this chapter,
  7 30 to file a copy of the dispensing record with the department.
  7 31    b.  The department shall annually review a sample of records
  7 32 maintained under this chapter.
  7 33    2.  The department shall adopt rules to facilitate the
  7 34 collection of information regarding compliance with this
  7 35 chapter.  Except as otherwise required by law, the information
  8  1 collected shall not be a public record and shall not be made
  8  2 available for  inspection by the public.
  8  3    3.  The department shall generate and make available to the
  8  4 public an annual statistical report of information collected
  8  5 under subsection 2.
  8  6    Sec. 11.    7 30 to file a copy of the dispensing record with the department.
  7 31    b.  The department shall annually review a sample of records
  7 32 maintained under this chapter.
  7 33    2.  The department shall adopt rules to facilitate the
  7 34 collection of information regarding compliance with this
  7 35 chapter.  Except as otherwise required by law, the information
  8  1 collected shall not be a public record and shall not be made
  8  2 available for  inspection by the public.
  8  3    3.  The department shall generate and make available to the
  8  4 public an annual statistical report of information collected
  8  5 under subsection 2.
  8  6    Sec. 11.    7 31    b.  The department shall annually review a sample of records
  7 32 maintained under this chapter.

  7 34 collection of information regarding compliance with this

  8  1 collected shall not be a public record and shall not be made
  8  2 available for  inspection by the public.
  8  3    3.  The department shall generate and make available to the
  8  4 public an annual statistical report of information collected
  8  5 under subsection 2.

  8  5 under subsection 2.
  8  6    Sec. 11.    8  5 under subsection 2.
  8  6    Sec. 11.    8  6    Sec. 11.    8  7 wills, contracts, and other agreements.
  8  8    1.  A provision in a contract, will, or other agreement,
  8  9 whether written or oral, to the extent the provision would
  8 10 affect whether a person may make or rescind a request for
  8 11 medication to end the person's life pursuant to this chapter,
  8 12 shall not be valid.
  8 13    2.  An obligation owing under any contract shall not be
  8 14 conditioned or affected by the making or rescinding of a
  8 15 request by a person for medication to end the person's life
  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.
  8 17    Sec. 12.    8  8    1.  A provision in a contract, will, or other agreement,
  8  9 whether written or oral, to the extent the provision would
  8 10 affect whether a person may make or rescind a request for
  8 11 medication to end the person's life pursuant to this chapter,
  8 12 shall not be valid.
  8 13    2.  An obligation owing under any contract shall not be
  8 14 conditioned or affected by the making or rescinding of a
  8 15 request by a person for medication to end the person's life
  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.

  8 14 conditioned or affected by the making or rescinding of a
  8 15 request by a person for medication to end the person's life
  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.

  8 13    2.  An obligation owing under any contract shall not be
  8 14 conditioned or affected by the making or rescinding of a
  8 15 request by a person for medication to end the person's life
  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.

  8 14 conditioned or affected by the making or rescinding of a
  8 15 request by a person for medication to end the person's life
  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.

  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.
  8 17    Sec. 12.    8 15 request by a person for medication to end the person's life
  8 16 pursuant to this chapter.
  8 17    Sec. 12.    8 16 pursuant to this chapter.
  8 17    Sec. 12.    8 17    Sec. 12.    8 18 policies.
  8 19    The sale, procurement, or issuance of any life, health,
  8 20 or accident insurance or annuity policy or the rate charged
  8 21 for any such policy shall not be conditioned upon or affected
  8 22 by the making or rescinding of a request by a person for
  8 23 medication that may be self=administered to end the person's
  8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 19    The sale, procurement, or issuance of any life, health,
  8 20 or accident insurance or annuity policy or the rate charged
  8 21 for any such policy shall not be conditioned upon or affected
  8 22 by the making or rescinding of a request by a person for
  8 23 medication that may be self=administered to end the person's
  8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 20 or accident insurance or annuity policy or the rate charged
  8 21 for any such policy shall not be conditioned upon or affected
  8 22 by the making or rescinding of a request by a person for
  8 23 medication that may be self=administered to end the person's
  8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 21 for any such policy shall not be conditioned upon or affected
  8 22 by the making or rescinding of a request by a person for
  8 23 medication that may be self=administered to end the person's
  8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 22 by the making or rescinding of a request by a person for
  8 23 medication that may be self=administered to end the person's
  8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 23 medication that may be self=administered to end the person's
  8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 24 life pursuant to this chapter. A qualified patient's act of
  8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 25 self=administering medication to end the qualified patient's
  8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 26 life pursuant to this chapter shall not have an effect upon a
  8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 27 life, health, or accident insurance or annuity policy.
  8 28    Sec. 13.    8 28    Sec. 13.    8 29    1.  Nothing in this  chapter shall be construed to authorize
  8 30 a physician or any other person to end a patient's life by
  8 31 lethal injection, mercy killing, or active euthanasia. An
  8 32 action taken in accordance with this chapter shall not, for any
  8 33 purpose, constitute suicide, assisted suicide, mercy killing,
  8 34 or homicide under the law.
  8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    8 30 a physician or any other person to end a patient's life by
  8 31 lethal injection, mercy killing, or active euthanasia. An
  8 32 action taken in accordance with this chapter shall not, for any
  8 33 purpose, constitute suicide, assisted suicide, mercy killing,
  8 34 or homicide under the law.
  8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    8 31 lethal injection, mercy killing, or active euthanasia. An
  8 32 action taken in accordance with this chapter shall not, for any
  8 33 purpose, constitute suicide, assisted suicide, mercy killing,
  8 34 or homicide under the law.
  8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    8 32 action taken in accordance with this chapter shall not, for any
  8 33 purpose, constitute suicide, assisted suicide, mercy killing,
  8 34 or homicide under the law.
  8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    8 33 purpose, constitute suicide, assisted suicide, mercy killing,
  8 34 or homicide under the law.
  8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    8 34 or homicide under the law.
  8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    8 35    2.  Nothing in this chapter shall be interpreted to lessen
  9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    9  1 the applicable standard of care for an attending physician,
  9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    9  2 consulting physician, psychiatrist, psychologist, or other
  9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    9  3 health care provider acting under this chapter.
  9  4    Sec. 14.    9  4    Sec. 14.    9  5 for prohibiting health care provider from participation ====
  9  6 notification ==== permissible sanctions.
  9  7    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter:
  9  8    1.  A person shall not be subject to civil or criminal
  9  9 liability or professional disciplinary  action for acting
  9 10 in good=faith compliance with this chapter, including
  9 11 being present when a qualified patient self=administers the
  9 12 prescribed medication to end the qualified patient's life
  9 13 pursuant to this chapter.
  9 14    2.  A professional organization or association, or
  9 15 health care provider, shall not subject a person to censure,
  9 16 discipline, suspension, loss of license, loss of privileges,
  9 17 loss of  membership, or other penalty for acting or refusing to
  9 18 act in good=faith compliance with this chapter.
  9 19    3.  A request by a patient for or provision by an attending
  9 20 physician of medication in good=faith compliance with this
  9 21 chapter shall not constitute neglect under the law or provide
  9 22 the sole basis for the appointment of a guardian or conservator
  9 23 for the patient.
  9 24    4.  A health care provider shall not be under any duty,
  9 25 whether by contract, statute, or any other legal requirement,
  9 26 to participate in the provision to a qualified patient of
  9 27 medication to end the patient's life pursuant to this chapter.
  9 28 If a health care provider is unable or unwilling to carry out a
  9 29 patient's request under this chapter  and the patient transfers
  9 30 the patient's care to a new health care provider, the prior
  9 31 health care provider shall transfer, upon request, a copy of
  9 32 the patient's relevant medical records to the new health care
  9 33 provider.
  9 34    5.  a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  9 35 contrary, a health care provider may prohibit another health
 10  1 care provider from acting under this chapter on the premises
 10  2 of the prohibiting provider if the prohibiting provider has
 10  3 notified the health care provider of the prohibiting provider's
 10  4 policy regarding actions under this chapter. Nothing in this
 10  5 paragraph shall prevent a health care provider from providing
 10  6 health care services to a patient that do not constitute action
 10  7 under this chapter.
 10  8    b.  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section to the
 10  9 contrary,  a health  care provider may subject another health
 10 10 care provider to the following sanctions if the sanctioning
 10 11 health care provider has notified the sanctioned provider prior
 10 12 to action under this chapter that the health care provider
 10 13 prohibits actions under this chapter:
 10 14    (1)  Loss of privileges, loss of membership, or other
 10 15 sanction provided pursuant to the medical staff bylaws,
 10 16 policies, or procedures of the sanctioning health care provider
 10 17 if the sanctioned provider is a member of the sanctioning
 10 18 provider's medical staff and acts under this chapter while on
 10 19 the health care facility premises of the sanctioning health
 10 20 care provider, but not including the private medical office of
 10 21 a physician or other provider.
 10 22    (2)  Termination of a lease or other property contract or
 10 23 other nonmonetary remedies  provided by a lease or contract,
 10 24 not including loss or restriction of medical staff privileges
 10 25 or  exclusion from a provider panel, if the sanctioned
 10 26 provider acts under this chapter while on the premises of the
 10 27 sanctioning health care provider or on property that is owned
 10 28 by or under the direct control of the sanctioning health care
 10 29 provider.
 10 30    (3)  Termination of a contract or other nonmonetary remedies
 10 31 provided by a contract if the sanctioned provider acts under
 10 32 this chapter while acting in the course and scope of the
 10 33 sanctioned provider's capacity as an employee or independent
 10 34 contractor of the sanctioning health care provider. Nothing
 10 35 in this subparagraph shall be construed to prevent any of the
 11  1 following:
 11  2    (a)  A health care provider from acting under this chapter
 11  3 while acting  outside the course and scope of the provider's
 11  4 capacity as an employee or independent contractor.
 11  5    (b)  A patient from contracting with the patient's attending
 11  6 physician and consulting physician to act outside the course
 11  7 and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11  8 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.
 11  9    c.  A health care provider that imposes sanctions pursuant to
 11 10 paragraph "b" shall follow all due process and other procedures
 11 11 the sanctioning health care provider uses for the imposition of
 11 12 sanctions on other health care providers under the authority of
 11 13 the sanctioning health care provider.
 11 14    d.  For the purposes of this subsection:
 11 15    (1)  "Action under this chapter" means to perform the
 11 16 duties of an  attending physician, the consulting physician
 11 17 function, or the counseling function as specified under this
 11 18 chapter. "Action under this chapter" does not include any of
 11 19 the following:
 11 20    (a)  Making an initial determination that a patient has
 11 21 a terminal disease and informing the patient of the medical
 11 22 prognosis.
 11 23    (b)  Providing information about this chapter to a patient
 11 24 upon the  request of the patient.
 11 25    (c)  Providing a patient, upon the request of the patient,
 11 26 with a referral to another physician.
 11 27    (d)  A patient contracting with the patient's attending
 11 28 physician and consulting physician to act outside of the
 11 29 course and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11 30 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.
 11 31    (2)  "Notify" means a separate statement in writing to the
 11 32 health care provider  specifically informing the health care
 11 33 provider prior to the provider's action under this chapter of
 11 34 the sanctioning health care provider's policy about actions
 11 35 under this chapter.
 12  1    Sec. 15.    9  6 notification ==== permissible sanctions.
  9  7    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter:
  9  8    1.  A person shall not be subject to civil or criminal
  9  9 liability or professional disciplinary  action for acting
  9 10 in good=faith compliance with this chapter, including
  9 11 being present when a qualified patient self=administers the
  9 12 prescribed medication to end the qualified patient's life
  9 13 pursuant to this chapter.
  9 14    2.  A professional organization or association, or
  9 15 health care provider, shall not subject a person to censure,
  9 16 discipline, suspension, loss of license, loss of privileges,
  9 17 loss of  membership, or other penalty for acting or refusing to
  9 18 act in good=faith compliance with this chapter.
  9 19    3.  A request by a patient for or provision by an attending
  9 20 physician of medication in good=faith compliance with this
  9 21 chapter shall not constitute neglect under the law or provide
  9 22 the sole basis for the appointment of a guardian or conservator
  9 23 for the patient.
  9 24    4.  A health care provider shall not be under any duty,
  9 25 whether by contract, statute, or any other legal requirement,
  9 26 to participate in the provision to a qualified patient of
  9 27 medication to end the patient's life pursuant to this chapter.
  9 28 If a health care provider is unable or unwilling to carry out a
  9 29 patient's request under this chapter  and the patient transfers
  9 30 the patient's care to a new health care provider, the prior
  9 31 health care provider shall transfer, upon request, a copy of
  9 32 the patient's relevant medical records to the new health care
  9 33 provider.
  9 34    5.  a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  9 35 contrary, a health care provider may prohibit another health
 10  1 care provider from acting under this chapter on the premises
 10  2 of the prohibiting provider if the prohibiting provider has
 10  3 notified the health care provider of the prohibiting provider's
 10  4 policy regarding actions under this chapter. Nothing in this
 10  5 paragraph shall prevent a health care provider from providing
 10  6 health care services to a patient that do not constitute action
 10  7 under this chapter.
 10  8    b.  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section to the
 10  9 contrary,  a health  care provider may subject another health
 10 10 care provider to the following sanctions if the sanctioning
 10 11 health care provider has notified the sanctioned provider prior
 10 12 to action under this chapter that the health care provider
 10 13 prohibits actions under this chapter:
 10 14    (1)  Loss of privileges, loss of membership, or other
 10 15 sanction provided pursuant to the medical staff bylaws,
 10 16 policies, or procedures of the sanctioning health care provider
 10 17 if the sanctioned provider is a member of the sanctioning
 10 18 provider's medical staff and acts under this chapter while on
 10 19 the health care facility premises of the sanctioning health
 10 20 care provider, but not including the private medical office of
 10 21 a physician or other provider.
 10 22    (2)  Termination of a lease or other property contract or
 10 23 other nonmonetary remedies  provided by a lease or contract,
 10 24 not including loss or restriction of medical staff privileges
 10 25 or  exclusion from a provider panel, if the sanctioned
 10 26 provider acts under this chapter while on the premises of the
 10 27 sanctioning health care provider or on property that is owned
 10 28 by or under the direct control of the sanctioning health care
 10 29 provider.
 10 30    (3)  Termination of a contract or other nonmonetary remedies
 10 31 provided by a contract if the sanctioned provider acts under
 10 32 this chapter while acting in the course and scope of the
 10 33 sanctioned provider's capacity as an employee or independent
 10 34 contractor of the sanctioning health care provider. Nothing
 10 35 in this subparagraph shall be construed to prevent any of the
 11  1 following:
 11  2    (a)  A health care provider from acting under this chapter
 11  3 while acting  outside the course and scope of the provider's
 11  4 capacity as an employee or independent contractor.
 11  5    (b)  A patient from contracting with the patient's attending
 11  6 physician and consulting physician to act outside the course
 11  7 and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11  8 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.
 11  9    c.  A health care provider that imposes sanctions pursuant to
 11 10 paragraph "b" shall follow all due process and other procedures
 11 11 the sanctioning health care provider uses for the imposition of
 11 12 sanctions on other health care providers under the authority of
 11 13 the sanctioning health care provider.
 11 14    d.  For the purposes of this subsection:
 11 15    (1)  "Action under this chapter" means to perform the
 11 16 duties of an  attending physician, the consulting physician
 11 17 function, or the counseling function as specified under this
 11 18 chapter. "Action under this chapter" does not include any of
 11 19 the following:
 11 20    (a)  Making an initial determination that a patient has
 11 21 a terminal disease and informing the patient of the medical
 11 22 prognosis.
 11 23    (b)  Providing information about this chapter to a patient
 11 24 upon the  request of the patient.
 11 25    (c)  Providing a patient, upon the request of the patient,
 11 26 with a referral to another physician.

 11 28 physician and consulting physician to act outside of the
 11 29 course and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11 30 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.

 11 32 health care provider  specifically informing the health care
 11 33 provider prior to the provider's action under this chapter of
 11 34 the sanctioning health care provider's policy about actions
 11 35 under this chapter.

 11 16 duties of an  attending physician, the consulting physician
 11 17 function, or the counseling function as specified under this
 11 18 chapter. "Action under this chapter" does not include any of
 11 19 the following:
 11 20    (a)  Making an initial determination that a patient has
 11 21 a terminal disease and informing the patient of the medical
 11 22 prognosis.
 11 23    (b)  Providing information about this chapter to a patient
 11 24 upon the  request of the patient.
 11 25    (c)  Providing a patient, upon the request of the patient,
 11 26 with a referral to another physician.
 11 27    (d)  A patient contracting with the patient's attending
 11 28 physician and consulting physician to act outside of the
 11 29 course and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11 30 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.
 11 31    (2)  "Notify" means a separate statement in writing to the
 11 32 health care provider  specifically informing the health care
 11 33 provider prior to the provider's action under this chapter of
 11 34 the sanctioning health care provider's policy about actions
 11 35 under this chapter.
 12  1    Sec. 15.    9  8    1.  A person shall not be subject to civil or criminal
  9  9 liability or professional disciplinary  action for acting
  9 10 in good=faith compliance with this chapter, including
  9 11 being present when a qualified patient self=administers the
  9 12 prescribed medication to end the qualified patient's life
  9 13 pursuant to this chapter.
  9 14    2.  A professional organization or association, or
  9 15 health care provider, shall not subject a person to censure,
  9 16 discipline, suspension, loss of license, loss of privileges,
  9 17 loss of  membership, or other penalty for acting or refusing to
  9 18 act in good=faith compliance with this chapter.
  9 19    3.  A request by a patient for or provision by an attending
  9 20 physician of medication in good=faith compliance with this
  9 21 chapter shall not constitute neglect under the law or provide
  9 22 the sole basis for the appointment of a guardian or conservator
  9 23 for the patient.
  9 24    4.  A health care provider shall not be under any duty,
  9 25 whether by contract, statute, or any other legal requirement,
  9 26 to participate in the provision to a qualified patient of
  9 27 medication to end the patient's life pursuant to this chapter.
  9 28 If a health care provider is unable or unwilling to carry out a
  9 29 patient's request under this chapter  and the patient transfers
  9 30 the patient's care to a new health care provider, the prior
  9 31 health care provider shall transfer, upon request, a copy of
  9 32 the patient's relevant medical records to the new health care
  9 33 provider.
  9 34    5.  a.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the
  9 35 contrary, a health care provider may prohibit another health
 10  1 care provider from acting under this chapter on the premises
 10  2 of the prohibiting provider if the prohibiting provider has
 10  3 notified the health care provider of the prohibiting provider's
 10  4 policy regarding actions under this chapter. Nothing in this
 10  5 paragraph shall prevent a health care provider from providing
 10  6 health care services to a patient that do not constitute action
 10  7 under this chapter.
 10  8    b.  Notwithstanding the provisions of this section to the
 10  9 contrary,  a health  care provider may subject another health
 10 10 care provider to the following sanctions if the sanctioning
 10 11 health care provider has notified the sanctioned provider prior
 10 12 to action under this chapter that the health care provider
 10 13 prohibits actions under this chapter:
 10 14    (1)  Loss of privileges, loss of membership, or other
 10 15 sanction provided pursuant to the medical staff bylaws,
 10 16 policies, or procedures of the sanctioning health care provider
 10 17 if the sanctioned provider is a member of the sanctioning
 10 18 provider's medical staff and acts under this chapter while on
 10 19 the health care facility premises of the sanctioning health
 10 20 care provider, but not including the private medical office of
 10 21 a physician or other provider.
 10 22    (2)  Termination of a lease or other property contract or
 10 23 other nonmonetary remedies  provided by a lease or contract,
 10 24 not including loss or restriction of medical staff privileges
 10 25 or  exclusion from a provider panel, if the sanctioned
 10 26 provider acts under this chapter while on the premises of the
 10 27 sanctioning health care provider or on property that is owned
 10 28 by or under the direct control of the sanctioning health care
 10 29 provider.
 10 30    (3)  Termination of a contract or other nonmonetary remedies
 10 31 provided by a contract if the sanctioned provider acts under
 10 32 this chapter while acting in the course and scope of the
 10 33 sanctioned provider's capacity as an employee or independent
 10 34 contractor of the sanctioning health care provider. Nothing
 10 35 in this subparagraph shall be construed to prevent any of the
 11  1 following:
 11  2    (a)  A health care provider from acting under this chapter
 11  3 while acting  outside the course and scope of the provider's
 11  4 capacity as an employee or independent contractor.
 11  5    (b)  A patient from contracting with the patient's attending
 11  6 physician and consulting physician to act outside the course
 11  7 and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11  8 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.
 11  9    c.  A health care provider that imposes sanctions pursuant to
 11 10 paragraph "b" shall follow all due process and other procedures
 11 11 the sanctioning health care provider uses for the imposition of
 11 12 sanctions on other health care providers under the authority of
 11 13 the sanctioning health care provider.
 11 14    d.  For the purposes of this subsection:
 11 15    (1)  "Action under this chapter" means to perform the
 11 16 duties of an  attending physician, the consulting physician
 11 17 function, or the counseling function as specified under this
 11 18 chapter. "Action under this chapter" does not include any of
 11 19 the following:
 11 20    (a)  Making an initial determination that a patient has
 11 21 a terminal disease and informing the patient of the medical
 11 22 prognosis.
 11 23    (b)  Providing information about this chapter to a patient
 11 24 upon the  request of the patient.
 11 25    (c)  Providing a patient, upon the request of the patient,
 11 26 with a referral to another physician.
 11 27    (d)  A patient contracting with the patient's attending
 11 28 physician and consulting physician to act outside of the
 11 29 course and scope of the provider's capacity as an employee or
 11 30 independent contractor of the sanctioning health care provider.
 11 31    (2)  "Notify" means a separate statement in writing to the
 11 32 health care provider  specifically informing the health care
 11 33 provider prior to the provider's action under this chapter of
 11 34 the sanctioning health care provider's policy about actions
 11 35 under this chapter.

  9 13 pursuant to this chapter.
  9 14    2.  A professional organization or association, or
  9 15 health care provider, shall not subject a person to censure,

  9 32 the patient's relevant medical records to the new health care
  9 33 provider.

 10 29 provider.

 10 31 provided by a contract if the sanctioned provider acts under
 10 32 this chapter while acting in the course and scope of the
 10 33 sanctioned provider's capacity as an employee or independent

 10 35 in this subparagraph shall be construed to prevent any of the
